mn74:1.1.comm: This sutta records the occasion of the full enlightenment of the Buddha’s greatest disciple, Sāriputta, as well as the conversion of Dīghanakha. The commentary says this became the occasion for a unique four-factored gathering: it is the full moon in the month of Māgha; 1,250 mendicants spontaneously assemble; all were arahants with the six high knowledges; all were ordained by the “come, mendicant” formula. Today this is celebrated in the Makha Puja festival in Thailand.

mn74:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate sūkarakhatāyaṃ.
mn74:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain in the Boar’s Cave.

mn74:2.1.pli: Atha kho dīghanakho paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn74:2.1.eng: Then the wanderer Dīghanakha went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
mn74:2.1.comm: Dīghanakha means “Long-nails”; it must have been a nickname. Long nails are forbidden in the Vinaya (Kd 15:27.1.21) and also to the one performing a Brahmanical consecration (dīkṣā, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.2). Further, EA 34.4 says that long nails (爪長), uncut hair, and unwashed robes were disgraceful characteristics of ascetics. Ācārāṅgasūtra 2.8.5 speaks of the ascetic practice of abandoning the care of the hair of the head, beard, and nails. | Dīghanakha was Sāriputta’s nephew according to the Pali commentaries (not here, but in MN 111, SN 11.2, etc.) and northern texts such as Mahāprajñāpāramitā-upadeśa-śāstra, Mahāvibhāṣā, and Avadānaśataka.

mn74:2.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho dīghanakho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn74:2.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side and said to the Buddha,

mn74:2.3.eng: “Worthy Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:

mn74:2.4.comm: Dīghanakha’s view “nothing is acceptable to me” (sabbaṁ me nakkhamati) is obscure, which seems to be the point. Sanskrit and Tibetan parallels to this passage are identical to the Pali, so when some Chinese translations say “no view” or “no teaching” is acceptable, this is probably because the translators felt the need to clarify, echoing the common expression, “the acceptance of a view after consideration” (diṭṭhinijjhānakkhanti). This reading fits the text, but the sense may be broader than that. The closest phrasing in Pali is at DN 25:10.11, where “this is not acceptable to me” (idaṁ me nakkhamati) refers to food that a picky monk rejects. Views about acceptable food are recorded in detail in Jain texts, and we may presume that other orders had similar systems. Strictness in such matters is seen as a sign of virtue, escalating ultimately to the refusal of all food.

mn74:2.5.comm: Aggivessana is his Brahmanical clan name.

mn74:2.6.pli: ‘sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī’ti, esāpi te diṭṭhi nakkhamatī”ti?
mn74:2.6.comm: While this displays the Buddha’s ready wit, like much good humor it plays on a deeper anxiety. For it is easy to say that one believes in nothing, but the state of unknowing is psychologically unstable, as minds seek answers. When someone claims to hold no views, their skepticism is how they hide their views from themselves.

mn74:2.7.pli: “Esā ce me, bho gotama, diṭṭhi khameyya, taṃpassa tādisameva, taṃpassa tādisamevā”ti.
mn74:2.7.eng: “If I were to accept this view, worthy Gotama, it would make no difference, it would make no difference!”

mn74:3.1.pli: “Ato kho te, aggivessana, bahū hi bahutarā lokasmiṃ ye evamāhaṃsu:
mn74:3.1.eng: “Well, Aggivessana, there are many more in the world who say,

mn74:3.2.eng: ‘It would make no difference! It would make no difference!’

mn74:3.3.pli: Te tañceva diṭṭhiṃ nappajahanti aññañca diṭṭhiṃ upādiyanti.
mn74:3.3.eng: But they don’t give up that view, and they grasp another view.

mn74:3.4.pli: Ato kho te, aggivessana, tanū hi tanutarā lokasmiṃ ye evamāhaṃsu:
mn74:3.4.eng: And there are a scant few in the world who say,

mn74:3.5.eng: ‘It would make no difference! It would make no difference!’

mn74:3.6.pli: Te tañceva diṭṭhiṃ pajahanti aññañca diṭṭhiṃ na upādiyanti.
mn74:3.6.eng: And they give up that view by not grasping another view.

mn74:4.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn74:4.3.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn74:4.5.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:

mn74:4.6.eng: ‘Some things are acceptable to me and some things are not.’

mn74:4.7.pli: Tatraggivessana, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino: ‘sabbaṃ me khamatī’ti
mn74:4.7.eng: Regarding this, the view of the ascetics and brahmins to whom everything is acceptable

mn74:4.8.pli: tesamayaṃ diṭṭhi sārāgāya santike, saññogāya santike, abhinandanāya santike, ajjhosānāya santike, upādānāya santike;
mn74:4.8.eng: is close to greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.

mn74:4.9.pli: tatraggivessana ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino: ‘sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī’ti
mn74:4.9.eng: The view of the ascetics and brahmins to whom nothing is acceptable

mn74:4.10.pli: tesamayaṃ diṭṭhi asārāgāya santike, asaññogāya santike, anabhinandanāya santike, anajjhosānāya santike, anupādānāya santike”ti.
mn74:4.10.eng: is far from greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.”

mn74:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, dīghanakho paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn74:5.1.eng: When he said this, the wanderer Dīghanakha said to the Buddha,

mn74:5.2.pli: “ukkaṃseti me bhavaṃ gotamo diṭṭhigataṃ, samukkaṃseti me bhavaṃ gotamo diṭṭhigatan”ti.
mn74:5.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama commends my conviction! He recommends my conviction!”

mn74:5.3.eng: “Now, regarding the ascetics and brahmins to whom

mn74:5.4.eng: some things are acceptable and some things are not.

mn74:5.5.pli: Yā hi tesaṃ khamati sāyaṃ diṭṭhi sārāgāya santike, saññogāya santike, abhinandanāya santike, ajjhosānāya santike, upādānāya santike;
mn74:5.5.eng: Their view of what is acceptable is close to greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.

mn74:5.6.pli: yā hi tesaṃ nakkhamati sāyaṃ diṭṭhi asārāgāya santike, asaññogāya santike, anabhinandanāya santike, anajjhosānāya santike, anupādānāya santike.
mn74:5.6.eng: Their view of what is not acceptable is far from greed, bondage, approving, attachment, and grasping.

mn74:6.1.pli: Tatraggivessana, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn74:6.1.eng: When it comes to the view of the ascetics and brahmins to whom

mn74:6.3.eng: a sensible person reflects like this:

mn74:6.6.pli: imañce ahaṃ diṭṭhiṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa vohareyyaṃ—
mn74:6.6.eng: Suppose I were to obstinately stick to this view and insist,

mn74:6.7.eng: “This is the only truth, anything else is futile.”

mn74:6.8.eng: Then I’d argue with two individuals—

mn74:6.9.pli: yo cāyaṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi—sabbaṃ me nakkhamatīti,
mn74:6.9.eng: an ascetic or brahmin to whom nothing is acceptable,

mn74:6.10.pli: yo cāyaṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi—ekaccaṃ me khamati, ekaccaṃ me nakkhamatīti—
mn74:6.10.eng: and an ascetic or brahmin to whom some things are acceptable and some things are not.

mn74:6.12.pli: Iti viggahe sati vivādo, vivāde sati vighāto, vighāte sati vihesā’.
mn74:6.12.eng: And when there’s arguing, there’s dispute; when there’s dispute there’s distress; and when there’s distress there’s harm.’

mn74:6.13.pli: Iti so viggahañca vivādañca vighātañca vihesañca attani sampassamāno tañceva diṭṭhiṃ pajahati aññañca diṭṭhiṃ na upādiyati.
mn74:6.13.eng: So, considering in themselves the potential for argument, dispute, distress, and harm, they give up that view by not grasping another view.

mn74:6.14.pli: Evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ paṭinissaggo hoti.
mn74:6.14.eng: That’s how those views are given up and let go.

mn74:7.1.pli: Tatraggivessana, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn74:7.1.eng: When it comes to the view of the ascetics and brahmins to whom

mn74:7.3.eng: a sensible person reflects like this:

mn74:7.6.pli: imañce ahaṃ diṭṭhiṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa vohareyyaṃ—
mn74:7.6.eng: Suppose I were to obstinately stick to this view and insist,

mn74:7.7.eng: “This is the only truth, anything else is futile.”

mn74:7.8.eng: Then I’d argue with two individuals—

mn74:7.9.pli: yo cāyaṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi—sabbaṃ me khamatīti,
mn74:7.9.eng: an ascetic or brahmin to whom everything is acceptable,

mn74:7.10.pli: yo cāyaṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi—ekaccaṃ me khamati ekaccaṃ me nakkhamatīti—
mn74:7.10.eng: and an ascetic or brahmin to whom some things are acceptable and some things are not.

mn74:7.12.pli: Iti viggahe sati vivādo, vivāde sati vighāto, vighāte sati vihesā’.
mn74:7.12.eng: And when there’s arguing, there’s dispute; when there’s dispute there’s distress; and when there’s distress there’s harm.’

mn74:7.13.pli: Iti so viggahañca vivādañca vighātañca vihesañca attani sampassamāno tañceva diṭṭhiṃ pajahati aññañca diṭṭhiṃ na upādiyati.
mn74:7.13.eng: So, considering in themselves the potential for argument, dispute, distress, and harm, they give up that view by not grasping another view.

mn74:7.14.pli: Evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ paṭinissaggo hoti.
mn74:7.14.eng: That’s how those views are given up and let go.

mn74:8.1.pli: Tatraggivessana, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṃvādino evaṃdiṭṭhino:
mn74:8.1.eng: When it comes to the view of the ascetics and brahmins to whom

mn74:8.2.eng: some things are acceptable to me and some things are not,

mn74:8.3.eng: a sensible person reflects like this:

mn74:8.5.pli: ekaccaṃ me khamati, ekaccaṃ me nakkhamatīti,
mn74:8.5.eng: some things are acceptable and some things are not.

mn74:8.6.pli: imañce ahaṃ diṭṭhiṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa vohareyyaṃ—
mn74:8.6.eng: Suppose I were to obstinately stick to this view and insist,

mn74:8.7.eng: “This is the only truth, anything else is futile.”

mn74:8.8.eng: Then I’d argue with two individuals—

mn74:8.9.pli: yo cāyaṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi—sabbaṃ me khamatīti,
mn74:8.9.eng: an ascetic or brahmin to whom everything is acceptable,

mn74:8.10.pli: yo cāyaṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā evaṃvādī evaṃdiṭṭhi—sabbaṃ me nakkhamatīti—
mn74:8.10.eng: and an ascetic or brahmin to whom nothing is acceptable.

mn74:8.12.pli: Iti viggahe sati vivādo, vivāde sati vighāto, vighāte sati vihesā’.
mn74:8.12.eng: And when there’s arguing, there’s dispute; when there’s dispute there’s distress; and when there’s distress there’s harm.’

mn74:8.13.pli: Iti so viggahañca vivādañca vighātañca vihesañca attani sampassamāno tañceva diṭṭhiṃ pajahati aññañca diṭṭhiṃ na upādiyati.
mn74:8.13.eng: So, considering in themselves the potential for argument, dispute, distress, and harm, they give up that view by not grasping another view.

mn74:8.14.pli: Evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ paṭinissaggo hoti.
mn74:8.14.eng: That’s how those views are given up and let go.

mn74:9.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho panaggivessana, kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammo, aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassitabbo.
mn74:9.1.eng: Aggivessana, this body is formed. It’s made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction. You should see it as impermanent, as suffering, as diseased, as a boil, as a dart, as gloom, as an affliction, as alien, as breaking apart, as empty, as not-self.

mn74:9.2.pli: Tassimaṃ kāyaṃ aniccato dukkhato rogato gaṇḍato sallato aghato ābādhato parato palokato suññato anattato samanupassato yo kāyasmiṃ kāyachando kāyasneho kāyanvayatā sā pahīyati.
mn74:9.2.eng: Doing so, you’ll give up desire, affection, and subservience to the body.
mn74:9.2.comm: For kāyanvayatā (“subservience to the body”) see MN 36:4.4. The inclusion of this rare phrase here suggests that Jain-like practices such as starvation may be indicated.

mn74:10.2.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

mn74:10.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, aggivessana, samaye sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, neva tasmiṃ samaye dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti;
mn74:10.3.eng: At a time when you feel a pleasant feeling, you don’t feel a painful or neutral feeling;

mn74:10.4.eng: you only feel a pleasant feeling.

mn74:10.5.pli: Yasmiṃ, aggivessana, samaye dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, neva tasmiṃ samaye sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti;
mn74:10.5.eng: At a time when you feel a painful feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or neutral feeling;

mn74:10.6.eng: you only feel a painful feeling.

mn74:10.7.pli: Yasmiṃ, aggivessana, samaye adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, neva tasmiṃ samaye sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, na dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti;
mn74:10.7.eng: At a time when you feel a neutral feeling, you don’t feel a pleasant or painful feeling;

mn74:10.8.eng: you only feel a neutral feeling.

mn74:11.1.pli: Sukhāpi kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā;
mn74:11.1.eng: Pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings are impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated, liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

mn74:11.2.pli: dukkhāpi kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā;

mn74:11.3.pli: adukkhamasukhāpi kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā.

mn74:12.1.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, aggivessana, sutavā ariyasāvako sukhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, dukkhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, adukkhamasukhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati;
mn74:12.1.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.

mn74:12.2.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ, vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
mn74:12.2.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn74:12.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn74:12.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn74:13.1.pli: Evaṃ vimuttacitto kho, aggivessana, bhikkhu na kenaci saṃvadati, na kenaci vivadati, yañca loke vuttaṃ tena voharati, aparāmasan”ti.
mn74:13.1.eng: A mendicant whose mind is freed like this doesn’t side with anyone or dispute with anyone. They use the language of the world to communicate without getting stuck on it.”

mn74:14.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti bhagavantaṃ bījayamāno.
mn74:14.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.

mn74:14.3.pli: “tesaṃ tesaṃ kira no bhagavā dhammānaṃ abhiññā pahānamāha, tesaṃ tesaṃ kira no sugato dhammānaṃ abhiññā paṭinissaggamāhā”ti.
mn74:14.3.eng: “It seems the Buddha speaks of giving up and letting go all these things through direct knowledge.”

mn74:14.4.pli: Iti hidaṃ āyasmato sāriputtassa paṭisañcikkhato anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci.
mn74:14.4.eng: Reflecting like this, Venerable Sāriputta’s mind was freed from the defilements by not grasping.
mn74:14.4.comm: Sāriputta became a stream-enterer on hearing a short teaching from the monk Assaji (Kd 1:23.5.6), whereupon he told his friend Moggallāna. They both promptly left their former teacher Sañjaya, a traumatic loss to Sañjaya and his community. AN 4.172:2.1 says that Sāriputta became enlightened a fortnight after he ordained, a detail confirmed in multiple parallels to this passage; MN 111:2.8 details the practice he undertook in that fortnight. This means that the current discussion must have taken place only a fortnight after leaving Sañjaya. Now, Sañjaya’s philosophy was to systematically avoid taking any position (DN 2:32.2), which is similar to Dīghanakha’s doctrine. It seems likely, then, that Dīghanakha was a disciple of Sañjaya. This supposition finds support in several parallels, which say Dīghanakha was annoyed to learn that Sāriputta had rejected other teachers and gone over to the Buddha (eg. Avadānaśataka, Vaidya 1958a 256: sarve tīrthakarā nigṛhītāḥ; also in Mahāprajñāpāramitā-upadeśa-śāstra and Mahāvibhāṣā). These sources do not specify Sañjaya, but who else could it be?

mn74:15.1.pli: Dīghanakhassa pana paribbājakassa virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi:
mn74:15.1.eng: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the wanderer Dīghanakha:

mn74:15.2.eng: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”

mn74:15.3.pli: Atha kho dīghanakho paribbājako diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn74:15.3.eng: Then Dīghanakha saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha:

mn74:16.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evameva kho bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn74:16.2.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn74:16.3.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn74:16.3.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn74:16.4.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn74:16.4.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
mn74:16.4.comm: The Pali is alone in saying Dīghanakha became a lay follower, as all parallels report that he ordained and became an arahant. As with Vacchagotta at MN 72:22.2, it is unlikely that a wanderer would become a lay follower and the Pali is probably in error. | The Mahāprajñāpāramitā-upadeśa-śāstra, Tibetan Mūla-Sarvāstivāda-Vinaya, and Avadānaśataka say that, having cut his long nails before ordination, he was known by his actual name, Koṣṭhila, that is, the monk known in Pali as Mahākoṭṭhita. This contradicts the Pali tradition, but as Anālayo shows, there are several inconsistencies in the Pali accounts, so the northern tradition is credible (Comparative Study, vol. 1, p. 406, note 88).
